text:
S-X2
28. Keys, (Mrs. Joseph)
KEYE, Mrs. Jos.
Keystown, 1886 (with parents)

1. INTERDIARY USES
   That year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? Yes, I did.
   Where did you set up housekeeping? At Stanley, Green Bay, Wisconsin.
   How far had you been living before that? Never.
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Eight.
   How far was it to your nearest store? Four miles.
   How often could a visit be made to the store? When necessary.
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   For my own supplies at home, I prepared meals for six.
   How many more trips to town did you make each year?

2. FLOUR AND GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? No, I don't know.
   In what quantities did you buy flour? Small quantities of whole wheat flour.
   Was the usual price per hundred pounds of flour? No.
   How much did you use regular flour? None, we used only whole wheat flour.
   Was flour milled locally? Yes.
   Was the price for a twenty pound bag of flour? $1.50.
   What other grain products did you use? Wheat, cornmeal, oats, and rice.

3. FOOD PREPARATION
   Did you grind your own flour? Yes.
   How did you grind it? With a hand mill.
   There was mostly some white flour, though in limited quantities. A large quantity of porridge would be made in a pot, sliced when cold and fried in fresh dripping. The meal meal this course was cracked wheat.
Mrs. Mrs. Joe.
Keytown, 1866 (with parents)

1. INTERROGATION LISTINGS

What year did you start school in eastern Canada? With parents?
Where did you go to high school? At St. John's, Nova Scotia.
How far had you been living before that? None.
For how many years did you live there? 7.
How far was it to your nearest store? Unknown.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Unknown.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earlier years?
For any new things at times, prepared meals, yes.
How much from store? $11.

2. FLAX AND WOOL CULTIVATION

What brand of milk did you use in the early years? No.
What quantities did you buy? Small quantities, hard to say what.
Was the usual price per hundred pounds of milk to flour?
You used that flour? Yes.
Was that flour milled locally? Yes.
Was the price for a twenty pound bag or roll? $1.00.
That other grain products did you use? Wheat, corn, oats.
Cornmeal? Yes.
Did you grind your own flour? Yes.
How did you grind it? Stone mill.
There was mostly some white flour, though in limited quantities. A large quantity of porridge would be made in a pot, divided when cold and fried in pork dripping. The meal meal this flour was cooked with.
Kaye, Mrs. Jos.
Keystown. 1866. (with parents)

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and will fit.

Name: Mrs. Kaye
Address: Keystown, N.Y.
Phone: 222

1. INTER-DEPARTMENTAL USES

What year did you start housekeeping? 1900
Where did you get your housekeeping? Keystown, N.Y.
How long have you been living there? 1900
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 1 mile
How often could a visit be made to the store? Weekly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earlier years?
And the very necessary ones bought only by the necessity of living in my own home.

2. FLours AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? No particular
brand, as what you had was exchanged for flour from friends.
In what quantities did you buy? 100 lbs.
That was the usual price per hundred? 1.07
How much did you use regular flour? 100 lbs.
That was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 35¢
Whole wheat flour? Yes
That other grain products did you use? Wheat kernels, corn meal, rice
Commercially grown? Yes
Did you grind your own flour for pancakes? Yes
How did you grind it? Stone mill
There was mostly some whole flour, though in limited quantities. A large quantity of porridge would be made in morning, what was left would be packed in a box, dried when cold and fried in pork dripping. The meal meal flour because was cracked without
Mrs. Jos. 
Reynolds. 
1886. (with parents)

First started homesteaders, giving dates where possible.

Now there is hot and cold running water in the house.

Since 1911 - Drinking water has still to be hauled. Still water system is in operation with supply tank in attic.
13. SOAP
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kind of laundry soap did the grocer sell you? How long have you used this soap? Have you used any other brands in the last five years? If so, how long?

14. FUEL
What fuel did you use in your earliest days? Did you ever use oil? Have you used any other fuels? Mention any changes in the use of fuel which have taken place since you first started housekeeping.

Nowadays, what type of fuel do you use? Electric and gas furnaces are now being used (1950). The 18th century and earlier used wood, also electricity and gas and oil furnaces are now being used. Oil furnaces are being used to heat public buildings as well as rural homes.

15. HEATING AND COOKING APPLIANCES
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Did you use an outdoor fireplace or back oven? By whom was your first cook stove maker? What year was it purchased? What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, porcelain) For preparing food (chips, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Then did you first see steel pans? Aluminum?
13. COMFORT

14. FOOD

15. HEATING

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates.)

By whom was your first cook stove made? (Name, address)

What year was it purchased? (Give dates.)

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homestead)

Are there other...

Preparing Food? (Other, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

Then did you first use... (Give dates)
16. **SNAPSHOTS AND OWN MEMORIES**

   Contain any photos which you would like to include in the scrapbook and enclosures.

   Note: If the food was sent by mail in paper bags, label about 1932, Leo could be purchased in packages.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate number, etc., of guests.

   The breakfasts in 1886 consisted of porridge, milk, tea, or coffee, and the other two meals differed slightly with perhaps a small quantity of meat for dinner.

   Father 45 - Brother 18 - Mother 35 - Sister 23

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

   Yes, in 1886. Give the menu, lists those present, and five things approximately ages at that time.

   Helped to serve the first Christmas dinner in what is now Saskatchewan in 1886. The menu was little different from any other day.

   The older members of the family were away from home working, so do not recall how many were there.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

   Being one of the youngest of the family, do not remember ever being reduced to starvation level, but very often had to go after years, that the going much harder than very hard for the older ones. The hard years (1887) was so heavy that gardens or nothing else would grow. The only means of making a livelihood was by selling buffalo hides. These were piled up by the grain elevators. There were so plentiful, it was not necessary to travel a very great distance to sell a wagon load. The only complaint I heard was with a yoke of oxen.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) on the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, etc., in winter or summer.

The breakfasts in 1886 consisted of porridge, milk, tea for the older ones, some white bread, some molasses or syrup, and the other two meals differed slightly with perhaps a small quantity of meat for dinner.

Father 45 Son(s) 20 Daughter 11 Age in 1886 Mother 45 Brother 14 Myself 8 Sister 23 Brother 14

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? If so, give the date, list those present and five things appreciated at the time.

Helped to serve the first Christmas dinner as what is now called "turkey" in 1904. The menu was little different from any other day.

The older members of family were away from home homesteading, so do not recall how many were there.

19. Have you ever resided to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods?

Being one of the youngest of the family, do not remember ever being reduced to starvation level, but very often hung on after years, that the gang must have been very hard for the other ones. The land year (1889) was so very dry that gardens or nothing else raised grain. The only means of making a livelihood was by selling buffalo hides. These were piled up by the grain elevators. These were plentiful, it was not necessary to travel a very great distance to collect a wagon load; the only ordinance of travel was with a yoke of oxen.
There are many differences in the preparation of meals today compared with the earlier days. The earliest days used some simple and planning, then the housewife knew how to come by new and planning to make the food as far as possible. We always tried to eat the best we could, never all that was necessary in a bundle. Many kinds of canned meat, chicken and pork became, and many kinds of canned vegetables. They came in one and processed in glass cases.

21. When did you begin to rely on preserved foods? (Olives or canned fruits?)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of butter production and other foods in your pioneer life. Include things not mentioned above, quality, number of participants, price if more than $1.00 needed.

True things not mentioned earlier regarding butter. Shortly, was the abundance of milk. In the early years, milk was gathered from the cows and sheep near the Amish farm. The milk was then delivered to the Amish farm and churned. The Amish farm was also known as Nasholom, all of which were carefully gathered and preserved.

Something learned about buying provisions in my mind. Could not get much — fixed meal to chew. How Regina (25 miles away) when we always went there?
There are many differences in the preparation of meals today compared with the earlier days. The earliest days were hard times. There was no money and planning was essential. It was as far as possible. We always tried to save at all times.

In fact, there was little necessity in a large family of bread, sugar, butter, and many kinds of preserved meat.

When did you begin to rely on preserved foods? When did you begin to purchase canned goods?

Have you always had a garden? Have you always had fresh vegetables?

In October, there is a good supply of apples in all the stores. We have always had a good supply of canned meat, canned vegetables, and many kinds of canned vegetables. They are now more plentiful than ever before.

Please tell other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and other goods. Include any special stories or memories.

True, things not mentioned earlier regarding food in the early years. Meats were usually purchased in the fall when they were gathered by families. The Indians would gather in the fall and store them in the winter. The Indians would also store meat in the fall.

We were very careful about buying provisions in our second summer. We could not get much bread, meat, or cheese. However, we always used (more) oranges (25 miles away) where we always used (more).
There are many differences in the preparation of meals today compared with the earlier days. The earliest days were more thought and planning, though I know others the food was to come from and planning to make it go as far as possible. We always took time to read the menus, knew all that was necessary in a tough day of bread, bought butter and many kinds of prepared foods instead of home made bread or root vegetables. (Give as many details as possible.)

Have not yet begun to rely on purchased and prepared foods. Almost always have my own made bread. Have beef, pork, meat, poultry, etc., all the things that have always been there. Have our own canned meat as well as canned beans, and as many kinds of canned vegetables. They cannot be made processed in glass jars.

Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and supplies. Foods in other ways during pioneer days in southern Canada.

Ireland was not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems of storage, shortages, and other details. (Use back of paper if more space is needed.)

Some things not mentioned earlier, regarding our food supply, was the abundance of wild fruit in the early years. Strawberries covered the fields in the northern prairies. Raspberries were gathered by rail from the South West near the Canadian border. In addition, there were black cherries and choke cherries were to be had most years as well as blackberries, all of them were carefully gathered and preserved.

Something learned about buying groceries in my second former days 1900-1951 when not to forget anything. Could not get much bread, meat at store often.
There are many differences in the preparation of meals today compared with the earlier days. The earliest day's meal was simple and planning was necessary to make sure there was enough food and planning to make it go as far as possible. We always tried to use what we had, new all that is necessary in a tough life.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods instead of home prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

I have not yet begun to rely on purchased foods. I have always prepared my own food. Have beef, pork, meat, fish, and vegetables. We also have canned goods such as canned meat, canned vegetables, canned fruits, and canned vegetables. They are stored in glass jars.

22. Please list other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in eastern Canada.

Include items such as price, quality, methods of purchasing, and any other details.

If you could add any other details, please do so.

Some things not mentioned earlier regarding our food. Murphy was the abundance of wild fruit in the early years. Strawberries could be picked in the wilderness. Great near was gathered by Paul from the South West near the Cassiar River. Similarly, blackberries were gathered into the Athabasca Valley were black currants, gooseberries, and cranberries were to be had most years as well as Saskatoon berries, all of which were gathered and preserved.

Something learned about buying provisions in my second summer days (1900-1931) when not too much money was available. We always went over to Regina (25 miles away) where we always went over.
There are many differences in the preparation of meals today compared with those of earlier days. The emphasis has shifted from planning and preparing meals to convenience foods. However, there are still times when planning and preparing meals is necessary.

Many new methods have been developed over the years. For example, canned goods have become more common. However, canned goods should be used sparingly as they can be expensive.

In conclusion, while convenience foods have become more popular, it is important to remember that planning and preparing meals is still essential for a healthy diet.
There are many differences in the preparation of meals in the past compared with today. The earlier days included more thought and planning. Through the years, we have learned how to make do with what we have and planning has become less necessary. As we plan our meals, we always try to use what we have rather than go out and purchase. We also try to use a variety of foods.

Here are some tips to help you plan and save money:

1. Make a list of things you need to buy each week.
2. Plan your meals around what you already have in the refrigerator or pantry.
3. Use leftovers creatively.
4. Buy in bulk when possible.
5. Shop during sales.
6. Use coupons and discounts.
7. Prepare meals in advance.
8. Use recipes that use ingredients you already have.
9. Make sure you have all the ingredients before you start cooking.
10. Don't forget to save money by buying in bulk.

By following these tips, you can save money and still enjoy delicious meals.
